DPRK led by Kim Jong Il lauded
   Pyongyang, May 8 (KCNA) -- Alva Chavez, director of the board of the International Institute of the Juche Idea and a member of the executive committee of the Latin American Institute of the Juche Idea, attended round-table talks, hosted by the France-Korea Friendship Association, on the way home from his visit to the DPRK.   
   At the talks he said the Korean people are now  consolidating the independent national economy on the basis of strong defence power under the wise leadership of the great Kim Jong Il.
   He also briefed the participants on the Korean people's struggle to firmly  defend the Korean-style socialism in the teeth of the U.S and other reactionary forces' vicious moves  and to drive the U.S. aggressors  out of South Korea and reunify the country.   Thanks to the  correct line and wise leadership of   Kim Jong Il Korea will surely be reunified and become a powerful socialist nation.

Legislation to check evasion of military service
    Pyongyang, May 8 (KCNA) -- The South Korean authorities on May 3 passed through the "defense committee of the National Assembly" a bill on making it "compulsory" for high-ranking officials to open their record  of military service to the public, according to a radio report from Seoul.   
The bill calls upon not only the high-ranking officials but also their sons and grandsons to report to the "office of military manpower" their enlistment and discharge from the "ROK" army and the date and reason, if they were exempted from conscription. 
    The authorities set up the "joint investigation headquarters" to check the evasion of conscription growing among the South Korean people, and are getting overheated in arresting evaders.

Friendship gathering with delegation of IFRC
   Pyongyang, May 8 (KCNA) -- The central committee of the DPRK Red Cross Society sponsored a joint friendship gathering with members of a delegation of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) working in the DPRK, at the Pyongyang  Schoolchildren's Palace on Friday to mark a   "year of Red Cross and Red Crescent for the  21st century" which begins on May 8.   
Invited to the gathering were head Sten Swedlund and members of the IFRC delegation.
   Present were officials of the central committee of the DPRK Red Cross Society and other officials concerned.
   Participants went round circle rooms of the palace and saw an art performance given by schoolchildren.
   Then they talked with each other, deepening friendship.

S. Korean satellite launch ends in failure
   Pyongyang, May 8 (KCNA) -- A South Korean satellite, manufactured and launched by the United States, failed to go into orbit, a news report said.
The satellite "Orion" was made by the Hughes Inc. of the United States and "Delta 3" rocket carrying it by the Boeing.   
   The satellite-carrying rocket was launched at an airforce base in Florida, the U.S., on May 5 after more than four delays from April, but failed to go into orbit due to fuel exhaustion after the second-stage ignition.
   This failure, the fourth in recent one month, caused a loss of 2 billion dollars only in cost.
   Foreign news reports said that the failure seriously affected not only the satellite business of South Korea but also the U.S. aerospace industry.

Russian ambassador gives reception
     Pyongyang, May 8 (KCNA) -- Russian ambassador to Korea Valery Denisov gave a reception at the embassy on May 7 on the occasion of the 54th anniversary of the victory of the Soviet people in the great patriotic war.
Present on invitation were Ri In Gyu, vice-Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ri Song Ho, chairman of the DPRK-Russia Friendship Association and vice-chairman of the Korean Committee for Cultural Relations with Foreign Countries, and officials concerned.
   Speeches were made there.

Book on rules of wartime conduct released
   Pyongyang, May 8 (KCNA) -- The South Korean authorities published and distributed a book titled "National Defense Involving People" on Thursday as part of accelerated anti-north war preparations, according to a report from Seoul.
Contained in the book which has 59 articles are a series of rules of wartime conduct, including deployment and barrack discipline of "ROK" army units and conduct rules of "homeland reserve forces" under mobilization order.   The fact shows that the South Korean war hawks are putting war preparations against the north into a more concrete form.
   But only irrevocable destruction is waiting for those seeking a way out in invading the north.
